title: If by some medical breakthroughs, you were guaranteed a lifespan of at least 200 years, what would you do? - Quora

response.answer_text: I can’t say for sure, what I would personally do, but I have some ideas about what other people would do and how society would change if medical breakthroughs extended the average human life span to 200 years. I imagine the stages of life as we now interpret them, would change quite a bit. Like childhood, the teenage years, young adulthood, middle age, and elderly. The meanings of all these terms would change. What we now consider a “young adult” or a “middle-aged person” or an “elderly” person would all change. And the expectations of what is appropriate for people to do in those stages of life would change too. People would go through way more different stages and phases in their life than they do now. The show Futurama captured this idea really well. There was an episode where Professor Farnsworth, who is 160 years old, got to much of an anti aging serum and he regresses rapidly. His hair style and clothing and personality changed for every age and stage he went through. He went from being a middle aged professor type, to disco party guy, to a stoner hippy, to a nerdy acme covered teenager again, so a straight laced conservative type, to a nerdy little boy again, and a bunch of other different stages in between, that normally a person would only go through once in their life or not have enough time to change so many times. Maybe people would reach mental and emotional maturity at vastly different ages and it would become a lot harder to figure out a person’s age, just by knowing their life circumstances. For example, a 30 year old who still lives with their parents and doesn’t make a lot of money wouldn’t be seen as a loser, like they are in today’s society. Maybe a person in that situation would be looked at more the way society views a 19 year old in that situation today. Whereas their neighbor who is another 30 year old, married with kids and a well paying job, would also not be seen as weird either. They just felt ready for that at a younger age and society would be ok with that and not judge anyone. Or maybe, society would see 30 year olds who marry and have kids as weirdos because they’d be viewed as still practically babies themselves. We’d probably see a lot more people waiting to age 50 or older to have kids or get a career job. (assuming the breakthrough also allows women to safely naturally have kids at a much older age.) Age discrimination in the work place would disappear. Society wouldn’t judge people for doing the “right” or “wrong” things for their age. You probably wouldn’t even think about how old a person is, most of the time. We’d probably see lots of people having multiple generations of children with different spouses and the notion of a traditional family would change a lot more than it already has up until now.
